faq.question: What are the system requirements?
faq.answer: A recent version of Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, Apple Safari or Microsoft Edge is required to run Dithermark. If your browser version is from 2017 or later, you are most likely good to go. A laptop or desktop computer is recommended since the user interface benefits from larger screen sizes and larger images take up more memory and processing power, but not required.

faq.question: Is Dithermark open source?
faq.answer: YES! Dithermark is open source and released under the MIT license. You can get the source code on the Dithermark GitHub page.

faq.question: I think I’ve found a bug, what do I do?
Where do the random images come from?
faq.answer: The random images are provided by Unsplash, courtesy of their free photo API.

faq.question: Why does my browser crash when opening an image?
Why does opening an image from a URL not work?
Should I enable WebGL?
faq.answer: WebGL is enabled by default as it leverages the power of your GPU to complete tasks 30-100 times faster. Dithermark uses WebGL (when enabled) for everything except the error propogation dithers and optimize palette functionality. The only times when it might be advisable to disable WebGL is if you are noticing a large amount of artifacts in the random dithers, or you are opening images that are too large to fit in a single WebGL texture unit (you will see a warning if this is the case). If you do not see an option to enable WebGL, that means your device/browser doesn’t support it. In that case do not worry, as everything will still work, it will just be slower than if your device supported WebGL.

faq.question: How do I get rid of the artifacts in the random dithers?
What happened to my saved settings/palettes?
Why doesn’t the export/download button work?
faq.answer: On browsers lacking HTMLCanvasElement.toBlob() support (Apple Safari and Microsoft Edge), exporting a large image may fail. In that case, reset the zoom level to 100 and then right click on desktop/long press on mobile on the image you want to save. Select the ‘Save image’ or ‘Save image asâ€¦’ menu option to save the image as a png file.

faq.question: What file type should I use when exporting an image?
faq.answer: It is generally recommended you use the png file type when exporting your images, as it avoids undesirable compression artifacts. However, in certain situations (such as when exporting an unpixelated image), exporting as a jpeg might result in a smaller file in exchange for a small loss in quality.
